stem: A 55-year-old female with a history of type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with altered mental status, nausea, and vomiting. Initial assessment reveals the following. Select the findings that indicate possible Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA).

itemContext.sbar: Patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of Type 2 Diabetes presenting with altered mental status, nausea, and vomiting. Possible DKA.

rationale.correct: Elevated blood glucose, low pH, decreased bicarbonate, positive serum ketones, Kussmaul respirations, and fruity odor on breath are all indicative of DKA.
rationale.incorrect: Hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status, nausea/vomiting, dry mucous membranes, elevated potassium, elevated BUN/Creatinine, and tachypnea are common in DKA but not definitive diagnostic criteria. Low temperature and low sodium are not direct indicators of DKA, although they can be associated.
clinicalPearls: DKA is characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and ketonemia.
Kussmaul respirations are the body's attempt to compensate for metabolic acidosis by blowing off CO2.
A fruity odor on breath is due to the presence of ketones (acetone).

questionTrap.description: Students may choose signs and symptoms that are consistent with dehydration and altered mental status but are not specific to DKA.
questionTrap.focus: Differentiating between general dehydration and DKA-specific findings.

mnemonic.name: DKA Mnemonic
mnemonic.description: DEATH: Dehydration, Electrolyte imbalance, Acidosis, Total body potassium deficit, Hyperglycemia
